results.abstract: Gia Kourlas reviews solo show performed by Lance Gries as part of the La MaMa Moves] Dance Festival at LaMaMa ETC; photo (M)

headline.main: Under the Milky Way, In Suspended Reality

results.snippet: Lance Gries, a former member of the Trisha Brown Dance Company, presented a new solo, “Etudes for an Astronaut,” his first show in New York in 10 years.
results.lead_paragraph: La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, now in its sixth year, is frustratingly exhaustive, the kind of event that is overrun with too many mixed bills. But on Friday night there was an exception: Lance Gries, a former member of the Trisha Brown Dance Company, presented a new solo, his first show in New York in 10 years. ''Etudes for an Astronaut,'' described in program notes as ''one man's search for his place in the universe,'' was already in motion as the audience entered La MaMa's intimate club space. In head-to-toe black and flip-flops Mr. Gries repeated a movement sequence that gave his body -- through deceptively simple means of sitting, standing, leaning and rolling -- a sense of melting and hardening. In ''Etudes'' he is searching for balance between inner space (as in the mind) and outer space (the world). As Mr. Gries grappled with his many tasks (these included peeling off layers of clothes so that by the end he wore only a pair of shorts), there was absoluteness of intention. But while he showed he was able to expose raw nerves with great subtlety -- this has to do with the split-second shifts that his body undergoes throughout the performance -- he also drifted into a sketchy area of self-help. In ''Etudes'' there is a gap, in other words, between what he's doing and how he does it.

results.abstract: Why every musician and listener who uses a computer owes a debt to Max Mathews.
results.snippet: Why every musician and listener who uses a computer owes a debt to Max Mathews.
results.lead_paragraph: If the difference between 1911 and 2011 is electricity and computation, then Max Mathews is one of the five most important musicians of the 20th Century. - Miller Puckette

headline.main: A Diplomat, He Isn't: Prince Philip's Tongue Remains Sharp as Ever

keywords.name: persons
keywords.value: ELIZABETH II, QUEEN OF GREAT BRITAIN

results.snippet: He’s been called both a survivor of Britain’s imperial age and a national embarrassment, but Queen Elizabeth’s consort shows no sign on cutting back on his wildly offensive witticisms.
results.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- In a rare move by a man who appears to despise few activities more than speaking to the news media, Prince Philip recently agreed to cooperate in the making of a television documentary about his life. Although ''cooperate'' might be too strong a word. ''Well, so what? You just get old,'' a testy Philip is shown barking at the hapless interviewer, Alan Titchmarsh, who has just mentioned an award the prince received from The Oldie magazine. Asked if it was hard to give up his naval career when his wife became queen, Philip snorts, ''How long is a piece of string?''

results.abstract: Cameron Stephens, 17, worked unpaid for two weeks at Atlanta farmers' markets until an owner of one market hired him for the summer; photo (M)

headline.main: Tales of the Search for a Summer Job: To Get His Job, He Just Worked Until Somebody Noticed

results.snippet: ATLANTA -- Some teenagers search for jobs by asking their parents' friends. Others submit résumé after résumé online. And then there is Cameron Stephens's approach: work until they pay you.     Mr. Stephens, 17, a shy high school student in...
results.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA -- Some teenagers search for jobs by asking their parents' friends. Others submit résumé after résumé online. And then there is Cameron Stephens's approach: work until they pay you. Mr. Stephens, 17, a shy high school student in Atlanta, just started showing up at the job he wanted -- at a local farmers' market. He had never picked a vegetable, having always lived within city limits. He did not know what ''organic'' meant. But he drove by the weekly East Atlanta Village Farmers Market last summer and thought it ''seemed like a cool place to work.''

results.abstract: Photos of Rep Gabrielle Giffords are posted on her Facebook page, first clear public images of her since she began rehabilitation for bullet wound suffered in January Tucson shooting; photo (M)

headline.main: Photos Released as Giffords Prepares to Leave Hospital

results.snippet: PHOENIX -- Photographs of Representative Gabrielle Giffords were posted on her Facebook page Sunday, the first clear public images of her since she began rehabilitation from a bullet wound to the brain in January.     A spokesman said Ms. Giffords...
results.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX -- Photographs of Representative Gabrielle Giffords were posted on her Facebook page Sunday, the first clear public images of her since she began rehabilitation from a bullet wound to the brain in January. A spokesman said Ms. Giffords and her husband, the astronaut Mark E. Kelly, released the photographs in an effort to prevent her from being hounded by photographers when she leaves inpatient rehabilitation this month.

results.abstract: Representative Giffords's rehab at the Houston hospital will continue, although she will be an outpatient.

headline.main: Giffords Is Released From the Hospital

results.snippet: Representative Giffords's rehab at the Houston hospital will continue, although she will be an outpatient.
results.lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. -- More than five months after being shot point-blank in the head, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was released Wednesday from a Houston rehabilitation hospital where she had been relearning how to walk and talk, hospital officials said.

results.abstract: Rep Gabrielle Giffords is released from Houston rehabilitation hospital, more than five months after being shot point blank in the head; her therapy will continue on outpatient basis (M)

headline.main: Rep. Giffords Released From Houston Rehabilitation Center

results.snippet: Representative Gabby Giffords was released Wednesday from the Houston rehabilitation center, where she spent five months recovering from a gun-shot wound to the head.
results.lead_paragraph: TUCSON -- More than five months after being shot point blank in the head, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was released Wednesday from a Houston rehabilitation hospital where she had been relearning how to walk and talk, hospital officials said. Her therapy at TIRR Memorial Hermann will continue, although she will be an outpatient who commutes daily from the home that her astronaut husband, Mark E. Kelly, has in League City, Tex., near Houston.

results.abstract: Iran launches its second satellite into orbit, one that Western aerospace experts say could be used for limited military reconnaissance; experts say that the successful launching demonstrates Iranian engineers' growing skill (M)

headline.main: After Delay, Iranians Launch A Satellite

results.snippet: Experts say the long-delayed satellite might be used for limited military reconnaissance as well as for tracking earthquakes, floods and other natural disasters.
results.lead_paragraph: Iran said it launched a satellite into orbit on Wednesday that Western aerospace experts said could be used for limited military reconnaissance and also to monitor crops and track damage from earthquakes, flooding and other natural disasters. It was the second time that an Iranian rocket had carried a satellite into orbit and took place more than two years after Iran joined the international space club by launching its first satellite.

results.abstract: Exhibition at Stamford Museum and Nature Center examines Apollo 10 mission and addresses cartoon character Snoopy's role as NASA's safety mascot since 1968; cartoon (Metropolitan/Connecticut) (M)

headline.main: When Snoopy Landed on the Moon

results.snippet: With “To the Moon: Snoopy Soars With NASA,” the Stamford Museum and Nature Center gives a glimpse of the early years of Snoopy’s tenure as safety mascot for NASA.
results.lead_paragraph: IN March 1969, Charles M. Schulz created six sequential ''Peanuts'' cartoon strips following the pensive beagle Snoopy on a journey to the moon and back. They not only reflected America's anticipation of Apollo 11 -- the first manned lunar landing, which would take place in July of that year -- but also drew on the relationship between NASA and the ''Peanuts'' gang. That connection is the subject of ''To the Moon: Snoopy Soars With NASA,'' now on view at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. The exhibition made its debut in 2009 at the Charles M. Schulz Museum in Santa Rosa, Calif., to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Apollo 10 mission, which took place in May 1969 as a dress rehearsal for Apollo 11. The Apollo 10 crew had chosen ''Charlie Brown'' and ''Snoopy'' as the respective call names for their command and lunar modules. While the astronaut John W. Young orbited the moon in ''Charlie Brown,'' Thomas P. Stafford and Eugene A. Cernan piloted ''Snoopy'' within 50,000 feet of the moon's surface to scout a landing area for Apollo 11.

headline.main: Giffords and Husband to Write Memoir

results.lead_paragraph: Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona and her husband, the astronaut Mark E. Kelly, have made a deal to write a memoir of their lives together, their publisher said on Tuesday.

Last year, Mattel, the doll's maker, released "Mad Men" versions, giving Barbie a pile of fire-red hair and a fetching office-girl dress in her Joan Holloway incarnation.

results.abstract: Mattel releases three Barbie dolls inspired by great paintings (S)
results.snippet: Over the last half-century, Barbie has come in about as many guises and get-ups as Inspector Clouseau: cheerleader, supermodel, ski queen, doctor, astronaut, lawyer. Last year, Mattel, the doll's maker, released ''Mad Men'' versions, giving Barbie a...
results.lead_paragraph: Over the last half-century, Barbie has come in about as many guises and get-ups as Inspector Clouseau: cheerleader, supermodel, ski queen, doctor, astronaut, lawyer. Last year, Mattel, the doll's maker, released ''Mad Men'' versions, giving Barbie a pile of fire-red hair and a fetching office-girl dress in her Joan Holloway incarnation. Now, high art is taking a turn at a makeover. Three Barbies have just been released, inspired by great paintings, Tablet Magazine reported. One takes a crack at Mona Lisa -- a long overdue role for Barbie -- though the doll itself, with heavy eyeliner and a shower of curls, looks more like a model in an ad for a Renaissance fair. Another doll is inspired by Van Gogh's ''Starry Night,'' a painting that does not happen to feature a woman, so the Barbie is simply a blonde with a ''Starry Night''-print strapless gown.Undoubtedly the strangest of the three is the Barbie based on Gustav Klimt's ''Portrait of Adele Bloch I,'' the Viennese Secessionist masterpiece that Ronald Lauder bought for what some reported to be $135 million in 2006, one of the highest prices ever paid for an artwork. The Barbie, with a winged hairdo and a dress that gets the dazzling Byzantine mosaic pattern from the painting almost right -- minus Klimt's gold-leaf -- goes for $34.95.
